This application provides educational information and tracking tools. However, survey results do not replace a professional medical diagnosis. Always consult a doctor for an accurate diagnosis and proper medical examinations.
Nephrotic syndrome is a set of signs and symptoms indicating inflammation of the kidney filters (glomeruli), causing excessive protein loss in urine and swelling in various parts of the body.
• Dark, reddish or bloody urine (macroscopic hematuria)
• Mild swelling (edema) in face, eyelids, and ankles
Post-infectious glomerulonephritis is a kidney disease that occurs after an infection, commonly streptococcal pharyngitis or impetigo. The immune system mistakenly attacks the kidney glomeruli.
Please answer the following questions sincerely to assess possible symptoms related to kidney problems.
Have you noticed blood or dark coloration in your urine recently?
Do you experience swelling in face, hands, legs, or feet?
Have you had high blood pressure?
Have you decreased the amount of urine you produce?
Have you had any infection (throat, skin) in the last few weeks?
Do you feel more tired than usual?
Recommendation: Consult a doctor immediately for a complete evaluation.

Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney condition in which the kidneys lose large amounts of protein in the urine. This causes swelling (edema), especially in the feet, ankles, and around the eyes.

Proteinuria is the presence of abnormal amounts of protein in the urine. Under normal conditions, only minimal traces of protein should be present, but in nephrotic syndrome more than 3.5 grams can be lost per day.
Hypoalbuminemia is the low level of albumin in the blood. Albumin is a protein that helps maintain fluid within blood vessels. When it is lost in urine, fluid leaks into tissues causing swelling.
Hyperlipidemia is the increase of fats (lipids) in the blood. It occurs as the liver\'s response to protein loss, producing more cholesterol and triglycerides than normal.
Edema is swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body\'s tissues. In nephrotic syndrome, it occurs mainly in the legs, ankles, hands, and around the eyes.

Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis (PIGN) is an immune-mediated kidney disease that occurs after an infection, typically streptococcal. The immune system produces antibodies that mistakenly attack the glomeruli.
The glomerulus is the kidney\'s filtration unit. Each kidney has approximately one million glomeruli that function as tiny filters, removing waste and retaining essential proteins in the blood.
Immune complexes are combinations of antibodies and antigens that form during infections. In post-infectious GN, these complexes can deposit in the kidneys and cause inflammation.
Complement C3 is a protein of the immune system that helps fight infections. In post-infectious GN, its levels are usually low because it is consumed during the inflammatory response.
Hematuria is the presence of blood in the urine. It can be visible (red or brown urine) or microscopic. It is a common sign of inflammation in the kidneys.
Hypertension is high blood pressure. In kidney diseases, it occurs because the kidneys cannot properly regulate sodium and water, increasing blood volume and pressure.
Corticosteroids (like prednisone) are potent anti-inflammatory medications that suppress the immune system. They are used to reduce kidney inflammation and decrease protein loss.
Diuretics are medications that help eliminate excess fluid and salt from the body through urine. They are used to control edema and blood pressure in kidney diseases.
Dialysis is a treatment that temporarily replaces kidney function when they fail. It filters the blood to remove waste and excess fluid when the kidneys cannot do it.
A kidney biopsy is a procedure where a small tissue sample is taken from the kidney to examine it under a microscope. It helps determine the exact type of kidney disease and appropriate treatment.
Urinalysis is a fundamental test that detects proteins, blood, and other abnormal substances. It is the first tool for diagnosing and monitoring kidney diseases.
Blood tests measure kidney function (creatinine, BUN), protein levels (albumin), and other markers. They are essential for assessing the severity and progression of kidney disease.
